`,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff"}),` flag is used to turn on the service
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.writing"}),` is used to tell the service to write state diff objects it produces from synced ChainEvents directly to a configured Postgres database
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.workers"}),` is used to set the number of concurrent workers to process state diff objects and write them into the database
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.type"}),` is the type of database we write out to (current options: postgres, dump, file)
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.dump.dst"}),` is the destination to write to when operating in database dump mode (stdout, stderr, discard)
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.driver"}),` is the specific driver to use for the database (current options for postgres: pgx and sqlx)
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.host"}),` is the hostname/ip to dial to connect to the database
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.port"}),` is the port to dial to connect to the database
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.name"}),` is the name of the database to connect to
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.user"}),` is the user to connect to the database as
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.password"}),` is the password to use to connect to the database
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.conntimeout"}),` is the connection timeout (in seconds)
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.maxconns"}),` is the maximum number of database connections
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.minconns"}),` is the minimum number of database connections
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.maxidleconns"}),` is the maximum number of idle connections
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.maxconnidletime"}),` is the maximum lifetime for an idle connection (in seconds)
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.maxconnlifetime"}),` is the maximum lifetime for a connection (in seconds)
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.nodeid"}),` is the node id to use in the Postgres database
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--statediff.db.clientname"}),` is the client name to use in the Postgres database

`,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["Our Postgres schemas are built around a single IPFS backing Postgres IPLD blockstore table (",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"public.blocks"}),") that conforms with ",(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://github.com/ipfs/go-ds-sql/blob/master/postgres/postgres.go",children:"go-ds-sql"}),`.
All IPLD objects are stored in this table, where `,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"key"})," is the blockstore-prefixed multihash key for the IPLD object and ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"data"}),` contains
the bytes for the IPLD block (in the case of all Ethereum IPLDs, this is the RLP byte encoding of the Ethereum object).`]}),`
`,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[`The IPLD objects in this table can be traversed using an IPLD DAG interface, but since this table only maps multihash to raw IPLD object
it is not particularly useful for searching through the data by looking up Ethereum objects by their constituent fields
(e.g. by block number, tx source/recipient, state/storage trie node path). To improve the accessibility of these objects
we create an Ethereum `,(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{href:"https://github.com/ipld/specs#schemas-and-advanced-data-layouts",children:"advanced data layout"}),` (ADL) by generating secondary
indexes on top of the raw IPLDs in other Postgres tables.`]}),`
`,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:["These secondary index tables fall under the ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"eth"})," schema and follow an ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"{objectType}_cids"}),` naming convention.
These tables provide a view into individual fields of the underlying Ethereum IPLD objects, allowing lookups on these fields, and reference the raw IPLD objects stored in `,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"public.blocks"}),`
by foreign keys to their multihash keys.
Additionally, these tables maintain the hash-linked nature of Ethereum objects to one another. E.g. a storage trie node entry in the `,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"storage_cids"}),`
table contains a `,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"state_id"})," foreign key which references the ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"id"})," for the ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"state_cids"}),` entry that contains the state leaf node for the contract that storage node belongs to,
and in turn that `,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"state_cids"})," entry contains a ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"header_id"})," foreign key which references the ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"id"})," of the ",(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"header_cids"})," entry that contains the header for the block these state and storage nodes were updated (diffed)."]}),`
`,(0,n.jsxs)(e.h3,{id:"optimization",children:[(0,n.jsx)(e.a,{className:"subheading-anchor","aria-label":"Link to section",href:"#optimization",children:(0,n.jsx)(e.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Optimization"]}),`
`,(0,n.jsx)(e.p,{children:`On mainnet this process is extremely IO intensive and requires significant resources to allow it to keep up with the head of the chain.
The state diff processing time for a specific block is dependent on the number and complexity of the state changes that occur in a block and
the number of updated state nodes that are available in the in-memory cache vs must be retrieved from disc.`}),`
`,(0,n.jsxs)(e.p,{children:[`If memory permits, one means of improving the efficiency of this process is to increase the in-memory trie cache allocation.
This can be done by increasing the overall `,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--cache"}),` allocation and/or by increasing the % of the cache allocated to trie
usage with `,(0,n.jsx)(e.code,{children:"--cache.trie"}),"."]}),`

0x400 (1024 in decimal)

document.title: Documentation
document.description: Build your documentation site using Contentlayer and MDX.

body.raw:
Taxonomy includes a documentation site built using [Contentlayer](https://contentlayer.dev) and [MDX](http://mdxjs.com). ## Features It comes with the following features out of the box: 1. Write content using MDX. 2. Transform and validate content using Contentlayer. 3. MDX components such as `` and ``. 4. Support for table of contents. 5. Custom navigation with prev and next pager. 6. Beautiful code blocks using `rehype-pretty-code`. 7. Syntax highlighting using `shiki`. 8. Built-in search (_in progress_). 9. Dark mode (_in progress_). ## How is it built Click on a section below to learn how the documentation site built.
### Contentlayer Learn how to use MDX with Contentlayer. ### Components Using React components in Mardown. ### Code Blocks Beautiful code blocks with syntax highlighting. ### Style Guide View a sample page with all the styles.

body.raw:
## Motivation

The purposes of this document is to provide a design overview of Manifold Finance's *Sub Systems*. Subsystems are a 'collection of services that are viable'. Viable means that these services are production ready.

## Core Subsystems

The core subsystems are:

SecureRpc
Relay Service
Virtual Mempool

Applications, like OpenMEV, are built on these core subsystems. Below is a diaram expanding on the SecureRpc subsystem, detailing touchpoints such as fee generation opportunities and interfaces for 3rd parties to interact with (integrations).

![](https://d.pr/i/PaQ7t0.jpeg)

### Fee Types

relay operations
building  operations
blockspace capacity sales
fees from lending
fees from staking
fees from LPing
one time payments
fees from runnin validators
fees from owned protocol
fees from external protocols


## Network Subsystems

The core subsystems by themselves do not provide end to end connectivity or service availability. For such data availability requirements the Network Subsystem

![](https://d.pr/i/VsxdOs.jpeg)

document.title: User Guide
document.description: Advanced code blocks with highlighting, file names and more.

body.raw:
The code blocks on the documentation site and the blog are powered by [rehype-pretty-code](https://github.com/atomiks/rehype-pretty-code). The syntax highlighting is done using [shiki](https://github.com/shikijs/shiki).

It has the following features:

1. Beautiful code blocks with syntax highlighting.
2. Support for VS Code themes.
3. Works with hundreds of languages.
4. Line and word highlighting.
5. Support for line numbers.
6. Show code block titles using meta strings.

<Callout>

Thanks to Shiki, highlighting is done at build time. No JavaScript is sent to the client for runtime highlighting.

</Callout>

## Example

```ts showLineNumbers title="next.config.js" {3} /appDir: true/
import { withContentlayer } from "next-contentlayer"

/** @type {import('next').NextConfig} */
const nextConfig = {
  reactStrictMode: true,
  images: {
    domains: ["avatars.githubusercontent.com"],
  },
  experimental: {
    appDir: true,
    serverComponentsExternalPackages: ["@prisma/client"],
  },
}

export default withContentlayer(nextConfig)
```

## Title

````mdx
```ts title="path/to/file.ts"
// Code here
```
````

## Line Highlight

````mdx
```ts {1,3-6}
// Highlight line 1 and line 3 to 6
```
````

## Word Highlight

````mdx
```ts /shadcn/
// Highlight the word shadcn.
```
````

## Line Numbers

````mdx
```ts showLineNumbers
// This will show line numbers.
```
````
